Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

**Discharge Summary Letter**

Date: February 14, 2024

Patient Name: ___  
Age: 70  
Gender: Male  
Admission Date: February 10, 2024  
Discharge Date: February 14, 2024  

Dear ___,

I am writing to summarize the details of your recent hospitalization at our facility. You were admitted on February 10, 2024, with symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever, which were indicative of pneumonia. 

Upon admission, a diagnosis of lobar pneumonia, unspecified organism (ICD-10: J18.1) was established. Initial examination revealed a high temperature of 38.5°C, a heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure measuring 130/85 mmHg, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92%. A chest X-ray indicated consolidation in the left lower lobe, reinforcing the clinical impression of pneumonia.

Empirical antibiotic therapy with Amoxicillin intravenously was commenced, initially at a dosage of 500 mg every 8 hours, in conjunction with Paracetamol administered as needed. Laboratory tests on admission showed elevated inflammatory markers: a CRP level of 60 mg/L and a white blood cell (WBC) count of 12 x10^9/L. Your hemoglobin was 13.5 g/dL, and platelets were 250 x10^9/L.

Over the course of your stay, you showed steady signs of improvement. On February 11, your CRP level decreased to 50 mg/L, and your WBC count slightly decreased to 11 x10^9/L. By February 12, your temperature normalized to 37°C, and oxygen saturation stabilized at 96%. Consequently, a transition to oral antibiotics was planned and implemented the following day. Concurrently, Atorvastatin was administered nightly as part of your ongoing treatment regimen.

Further monitoring revealed continued clinical improvement, with CRP levels decreasing progressively to 20 mg/L and WBC to 7 x10^9/L by February 13. On the day of discharge, all vital signs were within the normal range, and your condition had significantly improved. You were deemed medically fit for discharge.

Upon discharge, you are advised to continue oral Amoxicillin at 250 mg daily for an additional five days. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in the outpatient clinic in two weeks to evaluate your recovery and ensure no recurrence or complications arise.

We appreciate the trust you have placed in our medical team, and we are happy to see your health restored. Please do not hesitate to contact our facility should you have any questions or concerns regarding your ongoing recovery.

Sincerely,

Dr. ___  
[Medical Professional's Title]  
[Hospital/Facility Name]
